node.text: In a bid to chip away at the remaining hesitancy regarding makeup on men, we asked the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers to do a pair of video tutorials demonstrating looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In the one shown here, she realizes a look inspired by the 1998 film “Velvet Goldmine,” with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect is meant to be one of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. Visit tmagazine.com for more. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Makeup for Men, or Anyone: Full-Face Glam

node.text: As part of T’s Beauty & Luxury issue, the writer @MeganEOGrady explores what makeup means to the growing group of men who have embraced it. Her piece is accompanied by photos of models with faces done by the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers, who, in a bid to make such adornment less intimidating, breaks down her process in a pair of video tutorials, demonstrating what she calls two “simplistic and masculine” looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In one video, she shares tips for creating dewy skin accented with a vivid swipe of color across the lids, and in another, she realizes a more classically glamorous visage with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect of both styles is a kind of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. See more on tmagazine.com. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Minimal Makeup Looks for Men — or Anyone

node.text: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives. Read Sandra E. Garcia's (@s_evangelina) accompanying story on this close-knit community on tmagazine.com. Video by @JoshuaKissi. Produced by Tom Delavan (@tdelavan).

node.title: Long Island's Enduring Black Beachfront Community

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Feb. 25 and 26, 2020, T gathered seven established black actresses — all of whom got their start decades ago, working across various mediums — for a group and cover shoot by the photographers @MickaleneThomas and @RacquelChevremont in Los Angeles, California. In it, these women — @HalleBerry, Angela Bassett (@im.angelabassett), @TarajiPHenson, Mary J. Blige (@therealmaryjblige), Lynn Whitfield (@mslynnwhitfield), @ViolaDavis and Kimberly Elise (@ikimberlyelise) — remember their first roles and discuss the solidarity they feel with one another. “We are living in an age in which some of our greatest, most successful actors are black women, near 50 or older, veterans who have fought against an industry that for much of its history would have rather ignored them,” writes @BrianKeithJackson in the accompanying story. Read more on Tmagazine.com. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Oct. 15, 2018, T gathered 32 black American male poets, playwrights and novelists — writers whose work is so crucial to our understanding America itself — at the Brooklyn Historical Society for a group portrait creative directed by @BootsRiley and this accompanying short film by @YvonneMichelleShirley. In it, these men reflect on their experiences and quote from some of their favorite works by black female American writers, whose voices are equally powerful and necessary. As Audre Lorde once said, “We don't only write about ourselves, we use ourselves to illuminate something that we really believe and we really feel.” Read the accompanying story, and why we chose to focus specifically on black men for this piece, on Tmagazine.com. You’ll also find a reading list chosen by these men of their favorite black female writers.

node.title: On Being a Black Male Writer in America

node.text: Around the country, restaurants are expanding their menus of thoughtful, complex, nonalcoholic cocktails to keep pace — especially this month — with a population that’s drinking less. And while these drinks are made for adult palates, they’re also drawing an unexpected fan base: children. T hosted a taste test, inviting children of the magazine’s staff and writers to assess several mocktails at @ReceptionBar.NYC, a modern Korean spot on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: A slew of restaurants across the country are offering premade picnic baskets these days, but if you're looking for something to whip up at home, well, it’s the season for that, too. We asked Dave and Krystiana Rizo, the owners of the Antonio-style taco joint Yellow Rose in Manhattan, for a couple of summery, picnic-friendly recipes. Two of their favorites are a salad of Tuscan-inspired grilled zucchini and a strawberry tomato soda, which Dave developed with Yellow Rose’s bar manager, Larissa Ciancarelli. The former, says Dave, is a perfect dish to take to the park or the beach “because it’s supposed to be eaten at room temperature and can be made hours ahead or right on an open flame.” (Just don’t overcook the zucchini, he advises; it should still have a little bite.) What’s more, he adds, the avocado dressing can do double duty as a dip for crudités. Click the link in our bio for the recipes, as well as our full guide to the perfect summer picnic. Written by Marian Bull (@mariantoro), photo by @FujioEmura, styled by Tim Ferro (@tfer21). #TSummerEntertaining

node.text: The sun is shining, the whole friend group is vaccinated and everyone is ready to make up for lost time. Sure, you could book a table for eight and eat inside at a restaurant — it’s still a thrill — but we just spent the last year figuring out how best to eat and socialize outside, and this summer is an opportunity to apply what we’ve learned. Restaurants, too, have adapted during the pandemic, working out which sandwiches wrap up best (sorry, sloppy Joes) and which cocktails translate well in to-go containers (it turns out there’s no bad receptacle for a margarita). And so we are living, it seems, in the golden age of the picnic.  Click the link in our bio for a list of some of the best spots across the country offering park-friendly fare, recommendations for colorful rugs and durable dinnerware to eat it on and two recipes for dining al fresco. Written by Marian Bull (@mariantoro), photo by @FujioEmura, styled by Tim Ferro (@tfer21). #TSummerEntertaining

node.text: #THouseTour: Art, flowers and fabrics are layered throughout Rosita Missoni’s house, a modern and airy two-story villa in Sumirago, some 30 miles northwest of Milan. Rosita and her husband, Ottavio, who co-founded @Missoni — best known for its rainbow-hued, chevron-patterned knits — in 1953, built the home in 1971, a few years after breaking ground on their factory, which is still in operation and located barely a minute’s walk away. “We wanted to live all the time where we would have liked to spend our weekends,” Rosita says of this verdant hollow at the foot of the Italian Alps. She especially liked that the property affords a view of Monte Rosa, which she could also see from her childhood home in the nearby city of Golasecca and which, at 90, she still finds delightful. “Most days, I wake up and take a photo of the mountain,” she says, scrolling through her camera roll past dozens of pictures of the pink-tinged peak. Then, before making her way to her studio at the factory, she might take a stroll through the property’s grounds and garden — a softly sloping lawn penned in by towering trees and blooming bushes — clipping coral peonies and blush pink dogwood blossoms as she goes. “I like all flowers except for white ones,” she pronounces while standing next to a neon magenta azalea. “I need to be surrounded by color.” Click the link in our bio for more. Written by @LauraMayTodd, video by Caterina Viganò (@caterina_vigano). #TSummerEntertaining

node.text: Follow along all week for more from T’s 2021 Summer Entertaining issue, which celebrates the season and the joy that comes with being able to share it, once again, with others. In addition to Matilda Goad’s and Butter Wakefield’s tips for making an oasis out of a modest outdoor space, and Mona Awad’s ode to eating cold cherries and watching Hitchcock, a tradition passed down from her mother, we’ll have party reports, a guide to throwing the ultimate picnic, a piece exploring the trend toward canned drinks and many others. #TSummerEntertaining

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 19, 2021. May be an image of cherries.

node.text:
Summer brings with it a certain set of rites and rituals — and everyone’s are personal and unique. For our weeklong ode to the season, T has invited writers to share their own. Here, Mona Awad (@misss_read) describes the simple pleasures of eating frozen cherries while watching films by Alfred Hitchcock, an evening ritual passed down by her mother: 
 
A few summers ago, I had to have hip surgery. “Might be a long recovery,” my surgeon warned. And as for its success? “We’ll see.” Four to six weeks of crutches followed by three to six months of physical therapy. Painkillers and ice. This would be my summer of uncertainty. This would be my summer of suspense and lying still. This would be my summer of Hitchcock and cold cherries.
It was a hot summer, even in the evenings. I remember it as windless. My world became very small, reduced to a half-darkened room. I would lie in the blue shade, a chilled bowl of cherries sweating against my scarred hip like an ice pack. There was the whir of the oscillating fan, the blinds that made the evening light stripe across my face, my crutches leaning against the nearby dresser for easy access. On my laptop screen, Jimmy Stewart sat slouched in a wheelchair, his broken leg in a cast as he waited for Grace Kelly in “Rear Window.” She would show up soon, a mirage in an Edith Head dress, while the world beyond roared with life and love, sex and death — and later, it would turn out, murder.
I ate a cold cherry from the bowl at my thigh: an icy, candied sweetness with depth and bite. It tasted as vivid as the Technicolor on my screen. The cherries were my bridge, my passport to that other world. The walls around me fell away, or I forgot them. 
 
Click the link in our bio to read the full story. #TSummerEntertaining

Pictured: Wayne Thiebaud’s “Dark Cherries” (1984). © Wayne Thiebaud/Licensed by VAGA at Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York. Collection of the McNay Art Museum, bequest of David J. Kvapil

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 19, 2021 tagging @carlottacardana, @matildagoad, @butterwakefield, and @ellie_pithers. May be an image of flower, tree and outdoors.

node.text: To fashion a small oasis at her London home, the homeware designer and creative consultant @MatildaGoad enlisted the help of the garden designer @ButterWakefield. “Though I grew up in the countryside, where my mum has a beautiful garden, I’d never had one myself,” Goad says. “I’d seen that Butter had done a tiny London patio which was really inventive.” For this space, they devised a plan that hinged on dividing the garden into sections — Goad wanted to shake up what could have been a formulaic layout. “A lot of people want a lawn in the middle and borders round the sides, but I thought it would be nice to walk through two hedges, and beyond the second hedge, the garden would open up into an outdoor dining area that catches the sun all day,” says Wakefield. In that section Goad plans to install a concrete-topped table, but, for now, makes do with an old wooden style that she often dresses up with Hungarian linen tablecloths, though the one shown here is by Summerill & Bishop. Hungarian linen “often comes in long stretches and is a heavier weight that absorbs stains easier,” she says. At the link in our bio, Goad and Wakefield share more tips for creating — and entertaining in — a bloom-filled outdoor space of your own. Written by Ellie Pithers (@ellie_pithers), photo by @CarlottaCardana. #TSummerEntertaining

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 18, 2021. May be an image of flower and indoor.

node.text: For Nana Meriwether, Cale (@drinkcale), her new brand of herbal wines, is more than a line of low-alcoholic beverages. “As one of very few Black female winemakers in the country, it’s my hope to inspire others while also offering a new way for everyone to imbibe more healthily,” she says. Made in the Napa Valley and influenced by the ancient winemaking techniques of the Greeks, Romans and Egyptians, each bottle of Cale is produced by infusing traditional grape varietals like chardonnay, pinot noir, riesling and merlot with organic botanicals and adaptogenic and functional herbs such as lemon balm, ginseng, reishi and stinging nettle. The results are naturally low in sugar and calories and allow for a more intentional drinking experience. Written by @MichaelaTrimble, photo by Meiwen See (@meiwens). #TList

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 18, 2021 tagging @masseriacalderisi. May be an image of beach, tree, ocean and nature.

node.text: @MasseriaCalderisi’s owners, Max and Jutta von Braunmühl, had been returning to Puglia — where the two were married in 2011 — for more than a decade in search of a property. After they finally found, and quickly snapped up, a 17th-century farm estate surrounded by almost 20 acres of gardens and olive groves, the couple spent two years meticulously renovating the main manor, which has an expansive courtyard and is enclosed by whitewashed walls, into a light-filled hotel with 24 rooms and suites. Jutta designed most of the interiors herself, mixing artisanal pieces such as ceramics, sculptures and plates by the local artist Enza Fasano  with Moroccan rugs, colorfully patterned tiles from the Amalfi coast and Pierre Frey pillows. Guests also have exclusive access to Calderisi Beach, a private strip of the Adriatic shore that’s just a 10-minute shuttle ride away. Written by Gisela Williams (@giselaatlarge), photo by Andreas Kusy.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 17, 2021 tagging @michonsandersart. May be an image of 5 people, people sitting and indoor.

node.text: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist. This week, we’re looking at “Seniors and Children First” (2020) by Michon Sanders (@michonsandersart), whose first solo show will open at San Francisco’s Friends Indeed Gallery in January 2022. “What you see is the repast, the meal after the wedding or the funeral or the church service or whatever the gathering is,” says Sanders. “It’s an unwritten rule that seniors and children eat first at gatherings, especially in the South. So it’s a group of folks who are all sitting down to eat — they’re talking, the meal’s probably wrapping up, there are some empty plates and folks are looking through photos, and then there’s a figure in the middle who catches your eye, who you realize is neither a senior nor a child — and it’s this instance of catching somebody in the act, maybe somewhere they’re not supposed to be. It’s just one of those in-between moments that happens in Black life.” Click the link in our bio for more.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: The shoe designer René Caovilla’s 15th-century Tuscan home — a former monastery — is located in the green, gentle hills of Chianti. In an entryway, an 18th-century Flemish tapestry hangs over a settee. Photo by @AlexisArmanet.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 16, 2021 tagging @reggienadelson, and @kalustyans. May be an image of drink and indoor.

node.text: For decades, @Kalustyans — the prodigiously stocked specialty food shop on New York's Lexington Avenue between East 28th and East 29th Streets — has carried those hard-to-find ingredients, and plenty of others that you didn’t even know you were looking for. “A few years ago, Yotam Ottolenghi’s cookbooks became popular, and people started asking for rose harissa,” says Dona Abramson, the store’s operations manager, who is sometimes thought of as the oracle of Kalustyan’s. “I tracked down the brand he mentioned, and now we import it from the U.K. We buy 50 cases at a time.” In the last decade or so, she realized “that cocktails were becoming huge.” And so, on the third level are all the fixings: orange bitters, chocolate bitters, hibiscus, lavender and oak bitters, Mexican mole bitters, Jamaican jerk bitters, peppermint and yuzu syrups. “I come here at least once a week,” says Anthony Baker, a well-known mixologist who has worked at the Crosby Hotel in New York. “I can find absolutely everything, including dried blue lotus slices for a cocktail garnish.” Click the link in our bio for @ReggieNadelson’s full story on the iconic store. Photo by Daniel Terna.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: The dining room of this Callicoon, N.Y., stone house merges contemporary objects with natural woods; a modern pendant lamp by Menu contrasts with the old hickory ceiling beams, and an Audubon illustration of owls hangs over the contemporary oak dining table. Photo by Matthew Williams.
